awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electronic and Geometric Structure of n-Glyme Assembled Metal Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal nanoparticles can be just a few nanometers in size and contain just tens to hundreds of metal atoms. When the nanoparticles are isolated from one another, exposure to light typically results in heating of the particle, which then dissipates energy into the surrounding solvent.  However, connect two particles together and that light absorption can be converted into a bright luminescence. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Christopher Ackerson (Colorado State University), Christine Aikens (Kansas State University), and Kenneth Knappenberger (Pennsylvania State University) are working to understand the mechanism of this light emission.  The team combines precision nanoparticle synthesis and characterization with cutting-edge theoretical calculations and experimental spectroscopy to determine the unique luminescence properties of these systems.  Their discoveries could improve bioimaging and impact emerging quantum information technologies. The project also provides a unique multi-disciplinary environment for student training, and outreach activities to K-12 students are introducing underrepresented students to scientific research. 

The primary thrusts of this proposal are to determine how ligand substitution affects the geometric and electronic structure of quantum-confined gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) and their assemblies, and to understand the influence of these properties on electronic relaxation dynamics and photoluminescence yields. The team is also developing an understanding of how the properties of AuNC monomers impact electronically coupled dimers and extended structures. The proposed research features structurally precise monolayer-protected gold clusters and progresses to include n-glyme-bridged multimers. The specific objectives include: 1) to determine the compatible ligands for which glyme molecules can be incorporated into the AuNC passivation shell, and to understand the range of clusters that can be assembled using glyme-driven chemistry; 2) to describe the nature of the interaction -- both electronically and geometrically -- of glyme with AuNC monomers and larger assemblies; and 3) to describe how the properties described in 1 and 2 affect state-resolved carrier dynamics of AuNC monomers, inter-cluster electronic coupling and transfer, and photoluminescence emission. These goals are being achieved by combining colloidal AuNC synthesis and purification, computational-based predictions, and experimental electron dynamics research. The proposed efforts include plans to provide student education at the graduate and undergraduate levels in three pillars of nanoscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Metal nanostructures can be used to control energy for many important applications, including solar-to-electric energy conversion, catalysis, and quantum information sciences, among others. Our research under this award has led to many key new understandings of how metal nanocluster and metal-ligand interfacial structure impact spin and magnetic properties of metal colloids. We developed new experimental capabilities to provide these structure-property correlations. This includes development of energy- and time-domain measurements that use high applied magnetic fields (17 T), which are approximately 1700x larger than a common refrigerator magnet and 10x stronger than at typical MRI magnet. This strong field has allowed us to resolve details about electron spin in metals, which can be important for spintronics and other quantum information applications. Our contributions and breakthroughs in experimental measurements have been described in several peer-reviewed publications and research presentations at universities, scientific conferences, and national laboratories. 

Intellectual Merit: 

I will highlight key findings that occurred in three primary areas during the activities this award related to metal nanostructures: 1) spin-polarized excitation; 2) spin-polarized emission; and 3) polarization resolved electron dynamics. They include describing the optical (plasmon) modes of nanoparticle heterostructures, identifying excitation mechanisms of vibrational modes in metal nanostructures, understanding energy transfer across semiconductor-molecule interfaces. 

Spin-polarized excitation. 

We used magnetic-field spectroscopy to detail spin-polarized excitation in a series of ligand-protected metal nanoclusters, spanning from atomic (quantum) to plasmonic (classical) behavior. Of particular interest is the 1.8-nanometer Au144(SC8H9)60 nanocluster, which exhibited 19 distinguishable magneto-optical absorption peaks in the visible range. We uncovered signatures of paramagnetism, diamagnetism, and non-discrete (i.e. mixed) excitations in an energy range spanning only 300 meV (Figure 1). The results show that gold-ligand interfaces have complex electronic spin and magnetic properties that can be developed in future research. 

Spin-polarized emission. 

We determined structural influences of spin-polarized nanocluster photoluminescence using superatomic Au25(SC8H9)18as a model system. We measured spin-polarization ratios of up to 20%, which is comparable to many leading 2D quantum materials (Figure 2a). Importantly, we found that the spin-polarization response is response to synthetic modifications such as metal-atom substation and ligand exchange. Therefore, ligand-protected nanoclusters afford many opportunities to use chemistry tools to influence spin properties. Another key outcome of this research phase was the first known detection of a size-scalable response to gold nanocluster emission. We quantified a volume-dependent energy barrier separating bright and dark states (Figure 2b). Dark states interact strongly with phonons, which degrade spin polarization. As such, the degree of spin polarization is directly linked to this energy gap. A consequence is that we demonstrated increased spin-polarized emission yields resulting from sample heating, rather than cooling. Although more work needs to be done in this area, this is a critical advance for developing useable spin devices. 

Polarization-resolved electron dynamics. 

We used ultrafast polarization-resolved 2D electronic spectroscopy to describe both orbital symmetry and spin polarization dynamics for metal nanoclusters. Understanding how the initial spin polarization prepared by an excitation pulse is transferred to a polarized emission state is critical for developing useful materials. Metal-ligand complexes smaller than a few nanometers are good candidates for spin and magnetic materials because of their strong spin-orbit coupling interactions. However, distinguishing spin-dependent from orbital contributions is a challenge – both can generate polarization ratios. Using a excitation phase, inter-pulse time delays, and polarization (circular, linear and elliptical) combinations we were able to isolate signals originating from specific orbital symmetries and spin processes. These capabilities will be carried forward in continuing research to understand the influence of strategic synthetic modifications on polarized carrier dynamics. 

Broader Impacts: I also contributed to education in nonlinear optics, magnetic-field spectroscopy, and nanoscience. This work resulted in the graduation of two PhD, two Masters and several undergraduate students, all of whom are now gainfully employed in academic, industrial, and government sectors. I have worked to develop regional student sections of the Coblentz Society, a scientific organization devoted to spectroscopy. I have organized numerous scientific conferences on metal nanoclusters and spectroscopy. 

The discovery of diverse magneto-optical properties in colloidal metals and metal-ligand interfaces opens new opportunities for chemistry in spin-dependent and quantum information sciences.
